channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Checks and Balance newsletter: How Donald Trump has maximised his power
item.description: Charlotte Howard, our New York bureau chief, reflects on the first year of the president’s second term

item.title: EU Backs $105 Billion Loan to Ukraine
item.description: But Belgium’s pushback prevented the bloc from using frozen Russian assets to aid Kyiv.

item.title: A War Film to Change All War Films
item.description: An Oscar-shortlisted documentary shows battle in startling clarity.

item.title: Misreading Iran
item.description: Scott Anderson’s “King of Kings” offers a timely picture of U.S. myopia and miscalculation in Tehran.

item.title: A Raucous Reckoning With Brazil’s Dictatorship
item.description: “The Secret Agent,” Brazil’s Oscars hopeful, probes an undigested history.

item.title: Jafar Panahi Has His Eyes on the Future
item.description: Iran’s most celebrated director asks what a world after the Islamic Republic might look like.

item.title: Why Is the New ‘Avatar’ Film So Bloodthirsty?
item.description: The latest installment in James Cameron’s cultural juggernaut reflects a sad realism about current affairs.

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Dec. 13: Chile votes, Russia-Ukraine negotiations continue, and Iran’s currency tumbles.

item.title: Europe Looks Beyond the United States
item.description: From Ukraine to South America, the EU is forging its own path.

item.title: Air Pollution Is Choking South Asia
item.description: Smog is crossing borders and wrecking lives.

item.title: Will Trump Order an Attack on Venezuela?
item.description: Former U.S. ambassador: “This was never a counternarcotics mission. This has always been a regime change mission.”

item.title: Donald Trump and the White Man’s Burden in Nigeria
item.description: US President Donald Trump recently threatened to take military action against Nigeria to save Christians from a “genocide.” Trump has three possible motives for making such a threat: his mercantilist quest for rare-earth minerals, his pandering to evangelical Christians, and his racist grievances.

item.title: Global Health Workers Strengthen US National Security
item.description: The US government’s new global health strategy calls for shifting 270,000 frontline health-care workers from US-funded NGO programs to recipient government payrolls. But this could cause an exodus from the profession, undermining the disease-surveillance system and putting American lives at risk.

item.title: Russia’s Chinese-Enabled Drone Supply Network Is Remaking Warfare
item.description: UAV cooperation with China is rapidly transforming Russia’s capacity for sustained, cost-effective, and scalable warfare – with implications stretching from Europe to the Pacific Ocean.

item.title: The US Is Selling H200 AI Chips to China – So Why Isn’t China Buying?
item.description: China’s H200 curbs suggest a willingness to sacrifice short-term AI performance to escape dependence on the U.S. tech ecosystem.

item.title: US Arms Sales to Taiwan Signal Policy Continuity
item.description: While the Trump administration’s approach to Taiwan is continuing to coalesce, current signs indicate no dramatic departure from long-standing positions.

item.title: Inside Hindu Nationalism: The Ideology Changing India
item.description: What is Hindu nationalism, really?

item.title: A Blood-Smuggling Scandal Reveals China’s Genetic Security Anxiety
item.description: A sprawling illegal trade in prenatal testing has triggered alarm – less about illegal sex selection than about who might end up with Chinese DNA.

item.title: Japan Voices Concerns as South Korea’s Hanwha Expands Stake in Australian Shipbuilder
item.description: The South Korean defense conglomerate will nearly double its stake in Austal, complicating efforts to protect Japanese technology and IP related to a new frigate.

item.title: South Korean President Reiterates Necessity of Tipping Balance on Inter-Korean Relations
item.description: During the Ministry of Unification and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ policy briefing, Lee Jae-myung warned that the two Korea “are becoming true enemies.”

item.title: Cover Story newsletter: Illustrating our Christmas issue
item.description: An exclusive look at how we designed our cover

item.title: Trump’s Big, Not-So-Beautiful Economic Mess
item.description: Despite US President Donald Trump’s promises to lower inflation, shrink deficits, and revive manufacturing, his tariff wars have imposed steep costs on key allies, triggered price spikes, and hurt American producers and farmers. Yet there is little evidence that Trump is prepared to change course.

item.title: There’s No Precedent for Ukraine’s Proposed Peace Deal
item.description: History doesn’t suggest a demilitarized zone in eastern Ukraine would work.

item.title: The AI War on Christmas
item.description: American politics has latched onto the idea that Christmas has somehow been sullied by foreigners, particularly non-Christians. In fact, the holiday has been corrupted by non-human entities: a set of algorithms that we flatteringly call artificial intelligence has desecrated the season’s music and holiday ritual.

item.title: Europe finds €90bn for Ukraine—but not from Russia
item.description: An EU “reparations loan” using frozen Russian money collapses

item.title: PS Commentators’ Best Reads in 2025
item.description: As technological advances and geopolitical turmoil transform our economies, this year’s recommended books challenge prevailing assumptions and prompt us to reconsider what we take for granted. Ranging from scholarly analyses to literary fiction, they illuminate the choices that will define the years ahead.

item.title: Bangladesh-India Relations Are Back on the Brink
item.description: Sharif Osman Bin Hadi, a figure from the July Uprising, was allegedly shot by an Awami League activist, who has reportedly fled to India.

item.title: Trump’s National Security Strategy Seeks to Make Europe Great Again
item.description: Alongside an indictment of the continent sits a sacrosanctity accorded to its civilization.

item.title: The Silver Lining of ‘Haiti Fatigue’
item.description: The Trump administration’s U.N. resolution reimagines international responses to humanitarian crises.

item.title: Trump’s Western Hemisphere Pivot Is Real
item.description: Enforcing a 21st-century Monroe Doctrine means recalibrating U.S. defense posture.

item.title: Are Japan and South Korea Poised for a Historic Breakthrough?
item.description: An unlikely partnership could allow Tokyo and Seoul to counter China.

item.title: Trump 2.0’s National Security Strategy and the Future of the International Order
item.description: Welcome to the post-American world.

item.title: Cambodia, Thailand Willing to Deescalate Border Conflict, Chinese FM Says
item.description: Beijing is playing a more active mediation role after taking a relatively low diplomatic profile during the conflict's first week.

item.title: A new era for political risk insurance
item.description: So you want to insure your business against the risks of war? It may not be as farfetched as you think.
